<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

6. Towards a mother (grandmother and great-grandmother) and a father (grandfather and great-grandfather) the same obedience must be shown as towards a teacher. [#4] 

[#4]:  Manu II, 228, 215.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
mātari pitaryācāryavacchuśrūṣā ॥ 5 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
mātr̥grahaṇēna pitāmahīprapitāmahyōrapi grahaṇam । pitr̥grahaṇēna pitāmahaprapitāmahayōḥ। sarva ētē ācāryavacchuśrūṣitavyāḥ ॥5॥
</details>
</details>

samāvr̥ttēna sarvē gurava upasaṁgrāhyāḥ 7
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

7. The feet of all Gurus must be embraced (every day) by a student who has returned home; [#5] 

[#5]:  The word Gurus, 'venerable persons,' includes besides the teacher and persons mentioned in the preceding Sūtra, an elder brother, a maternal uncle, and all others who are one's betters or elders. See above, I, 2, 6, 29-35.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
samāvr̥ttēna sarvē gurava upasaṅgrāhyāḥ ॥ 6 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
uktāścānuktāśca jyēṣṭhamrātr̥mātulādayaḥ sarvē gurava samāvr̥ttēnāharaharupasaṁgrāhyāḥ ॥
</details>
</details>

prōṣya ca samāgamē 8
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

8. And also on meeting them, after returning from a journey. [#6] 

[#6]:  'That is to say, whether he himself or "the venerable persons" undertook the journey.'--Haradatta.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
prōṣya ca samāgamē ।। 7॥

**ṭīkā**  
yadi svayaṁ prōṣya samāgatō bhavati । guravō vā prōṣya samāgatāḥ । vadāmi tē upasaṅgrāhyāḥ ॥ 7 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

bhrātr̥ṣu bhaginīṣu ca yathāpūrvamupasaṁgrahaṇam 9
</details>

<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

9. The feet of (elder) brothers and sisters must be embraced, according to the order of their seniority. [#7] 

[#7]:  Manu II, 133.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
bhrātr̥ṣu bhaginīṣu ca yathāpūrvamupasaṅgrahaṇam ॥ 8॥  

**ṭīkā**  
pūrvēṇaiva siddhē kramārthaṁ vacanam-yathāpūrvaṁ jyēṣṭhakramēṇēti ॥8॥
</details>
</details>

<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

10. And respect (must) always (be shown to one's elders and betters), according to the injunction [#8]  (given above and according to the order of their seniority).

[#8]:  See above, I, 4, 13, 2.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
nityā ca pūjā yathōpadēśam ॥ 9 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
[#1] 'pūjā varṇajyāyasāṁ kāryā, vr̥ddhatarāṇāṁ cē'tyupadēśānurōdhēna yā nityā pūjā sā yathāpūrvaṁ vr̥ddhakramēṇa ॥ 9 ॥  

[#1]: āpa0 dha0 1. 13 2, 3
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

r̥tvikśvaśurapitr̥vyamātulānavaravayasaḥ pratyutthāyābhivadēt 11
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

11. He shall salute an officiating priest, a father-in-law, a father's brother, and a mother's. brother, (though they may be) younger than he himself, and (when saluting) rise to meet them. [#9] 

[#9]:  Manu II, 130.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
r̥tvikśvaśurapitr̥vyamātulānavaravayasaḥ pratyutthāyā'bhivadēt ॥ 10 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
[#2]'trivarṣapūrvaḥ śrōtriyō'bhivādanamarhatī'ti vakṣyati । tēnāvaravayasa r̥tvigādayō'pyabhivādayantē । tānabhivādayamānān pratyutthāyābhivadēt । nānyēṣviva sukhamāsīnō'bhivadati। vayasta utkr̥ṣṭānāṁ tēṣāmiyamēva pūjā ॥10॥  

[#2]: āpa0 dha0 1. 14. 13
</details>
</details>

tūṣṇīṁ vōpasaṁgr̥hṇīyāt 12
</details>

<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

12. Or he may silently embrace their feet. [#10] 

[#10]:  The commentator adds that the mode of salutation must depend on their learning and virtue,
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
tūṣṇīṁ vōpasaṁgr̥hṇīyāt ॥ 11 ॥

athavā pratyutthāya svayamapi tāstūṣṇīmupasaṁgr̥hṇīyāt । vidyācāritrādyapēkṣō vikalpaḥ ॥ 11॥

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

daśavarṣaṁ paurasakhyaṁ pañcavarṣaṁ tu cāraṇam । trivarṣapūrvaḥ śrōtriyaḥ abhivādanamarhati 13
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

13. A friendship kept for ten years with fellow citizens (is a reason for giving a salutation, and so is) a friendship, contracted at school, which has lasted for five years. But a learned Brāhmaṇa (known) for less than three years, must be saluted. [#11] 

[#11]:  Manu II, 134.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
daśavarṣaṁ paurasakhyaṁ pañcavarṣaṁ tu cāraṇam ।  
trivarṣapūrvaḥ śrōtriyō'bhivādanamahati ॥ 12 ॥  

**prastāvaḥ**  
athābhivādyā ucyantē—  

**ṭīkā**  
purēbhavaṁ pauram । pauraṁ ca tatsakhyaṁ ca paurasakhyaṁ sēvādinibandhanaṁ bāndhavaṁ tadabhivādanasya nimittam । kīdr̥śam ? daśavarṣāntarālaṁ, daśavarṣādhikaḥ paurassakhā aśrōtriyō'pyabhivādya iti vivakṣitam। pañcavarṣaṁ tu cāraṇam । sakhyamityupasamastamapyapēkṣyatē। cāraṇaśabdaḥ śākhādhyāyiṣu rūḍhaḥ । tēṣāṁ sakhyaṁ pañcavarṣamabhivādanasya nimittam । [#3]śrōtriyaṁ vakṣyati । trivarṣapūrvaḥ śrōtiyō'bhivādanamarhati । sa trivarṣapūrvatāmātrēṇābhivādanamarhati, na pūrvasaṁstavamapēkṣatē ॥ 12॥

[#3]: āpa0 dha0 2.6.4.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

jñāyamānē vayōviśēṣē vr̥ddhatarāyābhivādyam 14
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

14. If the age (of several persons whom one meets) is exactly known, one must salute the eldest (first).
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
jñāyamānē vayōviśēṣē vr̥ddhatarāyā'bhivādyam ॥ 13 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
kramārthamidam[#1] vayōviśēṣē jñāyamānē pūrvaṁ vr̥ddhatarāyā'bhivādyam abhivādanaṁ kartavyam ! paścādvr̥ddhāyēti ॥ 13 ॥  

[#1]: 'vacana'mityadhikaṁ kha. pu.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

viṣamagatāyāguravē nābhivādyam 15
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

15. He need not salute a person, who is not a Guru, and who stands in a lower or higher place than he himself.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
viṣamagatāyā'guravē nābhivādyam ॥ 14 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
uccaisthānē nīcaissthānē vā'vasthitō viṣamagataḥ । tasmai guruvyatiriktāya nābhivādyam । guravē svābhivādyamēva, darśanē sati tūṣṇīmavasthānasyā'yuktatvāt ॥ 14॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

anvāruhya vābhivādayīta 16
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

16. Or he may descend or ascend (to the place where such a person stands) and salute him. [#12] 

[#12]:  This Sūtra, like the preceding, refers to those who are not 'Gurus.'
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
anvāruhya vābhivādayīta ॥ 15 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
idamaguruviṣayam । yatrāsāvabhivādanīyaḥ sthitaḥ tatrānvāruhyābhivādayīta abhivadēt । anvavaruhyētyapi draṣṭavyam, nyāyasya tulyatvāt । gurau tu dr̥ṣṭamātra ēvābhivādanamityuktam ॥ 15 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

sarvatra tu pratyutthāyābhivādanam 17
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

17. But every one (Gurus and others) he shall salute, after having risen (from his seat). [#13] 

[#13]:  Manu II, 120.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
sarvatra tu pratyutthāyābhivādanam ॥ 16 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
sarvatra gurāvagurau ca pratyutthāyaivābhivādanaṁ kartavyam ॥16॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

aprayatēna nābhivādyam 18
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

18. If he is impure, he shall not salute (anybody); [#14] 

[#14]:  'Impure,' i.e. unfit for associating with others on account of the death of relations or through other causes, see below, I, 5, 15, 7 seq.

upāsanē gurūṇāṁ vr̥ddhānāmatithīnāṁ hōmē japyakarmaṇi bhōjana ācamanē svādhyāyē ca yajñōpavītī syāt 1

1. When he shows his respect to Gurus or aged persons or guests, when he offers a burnt-oblation (or other sacrifice), when he murmurs prayers at dinner, when sipping water and during the (daily) recitation of the Veda, his garment (or his sacrificial thread) shall pass over his left shoulder and under his right arm. [#1] 

[#1]:  15. Taitt. Ār. II, 1, 2 seq.; Manu IV, 58.

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
upāsanē gurūṇāṁ vr̥ddhānāmatithīnāṁ hōmē japyakarmaṇi bhōjana ācamanē svādhyāyē ca yajñōpavītī syāt ॥1॥  

**prastāvaḥ**  
sarvēṣāmēva karmaṇāṁ śēṣabhūtamācamanaṁ vidhāsyaṁstadupayōginō vidhīnāha —

**ṭīkā**  
gurūṇāmācāryādīnām , anyēṣāṁ ca vr̥ddhānāṁ pūjyānāmatithīnāṁ ca upāsanē yadā tānupāstē tadā, hōmē sāṅgē pitryādanyatra, japyakarmaṇi japakriyāyāṁ bhōjanācamanayōśca, svādhyāyādhyayanē ca, yajñōpavītī syāt yajñōpavītī bhavēt । vāsōvinyāsaviśēṣō yajñōpavītam[#1] 'dakṣiṇaṁ vāhumuddharatē'vadhattē savyamiti yajñōpavītam, iti brāhmaṇam । vāsasō'sambhavēnukalpaṁ vakṣyati 'api vā sūtramēvōpavītārtha' (2-4-22) iti । manurapyāha—  
[#2] kārpāsamupavītaṁ syādviprasyōrdhvakr̥taṁ trivr̥t ।   iti ॥  
[#3] uddhr̥tē dakṣiṇē pāṇāvupavītyucyatē budhaiḥ ॥ iti ca ।   ēṣu karmasu yajñōpavītavidhānātkālāntarē nāvaśyambhāvaḥ ॥ 1 ॥   

[#1]: tai0 ā0 2. 1.  

[#2]: ma0 smr̥0 2. 44.  

[#3]:

    ma0 smr̥0 2. 63. 'dvijaḥ' iti kha. ca. pustakayōḥ mudritamanusmr̥tipustakē ca ।
</details>
</details>

bhūmigatāsvapsvācamya prayatō bhavati 2
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

2. By sipping (pure) water, that has been collected on the ground, he becomes pure. [#2] 

[#2]:  Pure water is that which a cow will drink. Yājñ. I, 192; Manu V, 128.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
bhūmigatāsvapvācamya prayatō bhavati ॥2॥  
**ṭīkā**    
[#4]āpaḥ śuddhā bhūmigatā vaitr̥ṣṇyaṁ yāsu gōrbhavēt ।  
avyāptāścēdamēdhyēna gandhavarṇarasānvitāḥ[#5] ॥ iti manuḥ ।  
'śuci gātr̥ptikr̥tōyaṁ prakr̥tisthaṁ mahīgatam' iti । yājñavalkya.  
[#6] ajā gāvō mahiṣyaśca brāhmaṇī ca prasūtikā! daśarātrēṇa śudhyanti bhūmiṣṭhaṁ ca navōdakam ॥' [#7]iti ।  
śrāvaṇē māsi samprāptē sarvā nadyaḥ rajasvalāḥ[#1] ।  
iti smr̥tyantaram । ēvaṁbhūtadōṣarahitāsvapasvācamya prayatō bhavati । prāyatyārthamācamanaṁ bhūmigatāsvapsu kartavyamiti ॥ 2॥  

[#4]:

    yajñōpavītavidhānāt iti, kha. pu.

[#5]:

    ma0 smr̥0 5. 127. yā. smr̥. 1.192  

[#6]:

    ayaṁ ślākō mudritamanusmr̥tipustakēṣu nōpalabhyatē ।

[#7]: 'manuḥ' iti ka.pu.  

[#1]:  

    ētadanantara 'tridinaṁ ca caturtha'nhi śuddhāssyurjāhnavī yathā' ityardhamadhikaṁ dr̥śyatē ga. pu. smr̥tyantaraṁ' iti ca nāsti
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

yaṁ vā prayata ācāmayēt 3
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

3. Or he, whom a pure person causes to sip water, (becomes also pure). [#3] 

[#3]:  The ceremony of 'sipping water' may be performed in two ways; either the 'person sipping' may take the water out of a river, pond, &c., or he may get the water poured into his hand by another person. But, according to Āpastamba, he must not take a pot or gourd in his left hand and pour the water into his right, as some Smṛtis allow. The reason for this rule is, that Āpastamba considers it essential that both hands should be used in conveying the water to the mouth; see also above, I, 1, 4, 21. This agrees with the custom now followed, which is to bend the right hand into the form of a cow's ear, and to touch the right wrist with the left hand while drinking.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
yaṁ vā prayata ācamayēt ॥ 3 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
yaṁ vā prayatō'nya ācamayēt sō'pi prayatō bhavati । sarvathā svayaṁ vāmahastāvarjitābhiradbhirācamanaṁ na bhavati । ētēna śāstrāntarōkta kamaṇḍaludhāraṇamapyācāryasyā'nabhimataṁ lakṣyatē। alābupātrēṇa nālikērapātrēṇa vā svayamācamanamācaranti śiṣṭāḥ ॥ 3॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

na varṣadhārāsvācāmēt 4
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

4. He shall not sip rain-drops. [#4] 

[#4]:  'Some think, that this Sūtra is intended to forbid also the drinking of rain-water. Other commentators declare that, according to this Sūtra, it is allowed to use for "sipping" drops of water which fall from a vessel suspended by ropes [because the Sūtra emphatically excludes "rain-drops only].'--Haradatta.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
na varṣadhārāsvācāmēt ॥ 4 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
pūrvōktēna prakārēṇa prāyatyārthasyācamanasya varṣadhārāsu prasaṅgābhāvāt pipāsitasya pānapratiṣēdhārthamiti kēcit । apara āha-asmādēva pratiṣēdhācchikyādisthakarakādēryā dhārā tatra prāyatyārthamācamanaṁ[#2] bhavatīti ॥ 4॥  

[#2]:

    na bhavatyēva iti kha. ga. pu
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

tathā pradarōdakē +++(svayaṁbhuvi gartē)+++ 5
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

5. (He shall not sip water) from a (natural) cleft in the ground.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
tathā[#3] pradarōdakē ॥5॥  

**ṭīkā**  
bhūmēḥ svayaṁ dīrṇaḥ pradēśaḥ pradara tatra yadudakaṁ tasmin bhūmigatē'pi nā''cāmēt ॥ 5॥  

[#3]:  

    tasmāt pradarādudakaṁ nācāmēt' iti taittirīyabrāhmaṇam ।

taptābhiścākāraṇāt 6

<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

6. He shall not sip water heated (at the fire) except for a particular reason (as sickness). [#5] 

[#5]:  Manu II, 61. 'Because the term "heated by fire" is used, there is no objection to water heated by the rays of the sun. In the same manner the use of, "hot" water only is usually forbidden in the Smṛtis.'-- Haradatta.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
taptābhiścā'kāraṇāt ॥ 6 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
taptābhiradbhirnācāmēt akāraṇāt jvarādau kāraṇē sati na dōṣaḥ । 'taptābhi'riti vacanāt śr̥taśītābhiradōṣaḥ। tathā cōṣṇānāmēva pratiṣēdhaḥ smr̥tiṣu [#4]prāyō bhavati ॥ 6 ॥

[#4]:

    prāyaśaḥ iti. kha. pu. smr̥tiṣu । ityantamēva ca pustakē ।

- riktapāṇir vayasa udyamyāpa upaspr̥śēt 7

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

7. He who raises his empty hands (in order to scare) birds, (becomes impure and) shall wash (his hands). [#6] 

[#6]:  'Because the phrase "with empty hands" is used, he commits no fault if he raises his hand, holding a stick or a clod. Some declare, that the term "touching water" (rendered by "washing means "sipping water."'--Haradatta.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
riktapāṇirvayasa udyamyā'pa upaspr̥śēt ॥ 7॥  

**ṭīkā**  
vaya iti pakṣināma । yō riktapāṇissan vayasē pakṣiṇa idyamya tasya prōtsāraṇāya pāṇimudyacchatē sa tatkr̥tvā'pa upaspuśēt tēnaiva pāṇinā। 'riktapāṇi'riti vacanāt kāṣṭhalōṣṭādisahitasya pāṇērudyamanē na dōṣaḥ । kēcidupasparśanamācamanamāhuḥ ॥ 7 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

śaktiviṣayē na muhūrtamapyaprayataḥ syāt 8
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

8. If he can (find water to sip) he shall not remain impure (even) for a muhūrta.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
śaktiviṣayē na muhūrtamapyaprayataḥ syāt ॥ 8॥  

**ṭīkā**  
śaktau satyāṁ muhūrtamapyaprayatō na syāt । ācamanayōgyajalaṁ dr̥ṣṭvaiva mūtra purīṣādikaṁ kuryāt yadi tāvantaṁ kālaṁ[#1] vēgaṁ dhārayituṁ śaknuyāt iti ॥8॥  

[#1]:

    tāvantaṁ kālaṁ iti nāsti ka. pu.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

nagnō vā 9
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

9. Nor (shall he remain) naked (for a muhūrta if he can help it).
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
nagnō vā ॥ 9॥  

**ṭīkā**  
na muhūrtamapi syāditi sambadhyatē, śaktiviṣaya iti ca । vraṇādinā kaupīnācchādanāśaktau na dōṣaḥ ॥ 9॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

nāpsu sataḥ prayamaṇamvidyatē 10
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

10. Purification (by sipping water) shall not take place whilst he is (standing) in the water.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
nāpsu sataḥ prayamaṇaṁ vidyatē ॥ 10 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
yēna prayatō bhavati tatprayamaṇamācamanam । karaṇē lyuṭa । tadapsu satō vartamānasya na bhavati । jalamadhyē āsīnō'pi nācāmēt ॥ 10 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

uttīrya tvācāmēt 11
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

11. Also, when he has crossed a river, he shall purify himself by sipping water. [#7] 

[#7]:  The translation given above is based on the interpretation of Haradatta, who considers that Āpastamba holds 'crossing a river' to cause impurity. The natural and probably the right interpretation, however, is that rejected by Haradatta, 'But he shall sip water after having come out (of the river or tank).'
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
uttīrya tvācāmēt ॥ 11 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
tīra uttīryācāmēt na jala iti । ayamarthō na vidhēyaḥ । pūrvēṇa gatatvāt । tasmādayamarthaḥ-yadā nadīmuttarati nāvā prakārāntarēṇa vā tadā tāmuttīrya tīrāntaraṁ gataḥ prayatō'pyācāmēt । nadyādēruttaraṇamācamanasya nimittamiti । [#2]turapyarthaḥ ॥ 11 ॥  

[#2]: tuśabdō'pyarthē iti. ka. pu.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

nāprōkṣitamindhanamagnāvādadhyāt 12
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

12. He shall not place fuel on the fire, without having sprinkled it (with water). [#8] 

[#8]:  '"On the fire used for Vedic or Smārta sacrifices or for household purposes.". . . Some declare, that (the fuel need not be sprinkled with water) if used for the kitchen fire.'--Haradatta.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
nā'prōkṣitamindhanamagnāvādadhyāt ॥12॥  

**ṭīkā**  
śrōtē smārtē laukikē vā'gnau aprōkṣitamindhanaṁ nā''dadhyāt na prakṣipēt । kēcillaukikē nēcchanti ॥ 12 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

mūḍhasvastarē cāsaṁspr̥śann anyānaprayatānprayatō manyēta 13
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

13. (If he is seated in company with) other unclean persons on a seat consisting of a confused heap of straw, and does not touch them, he may consider himself pure.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
mūḍhasvastarē cāsaṁspr̥śannanyānaprayatānprayatō manyēta ॥ 13 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
[#3]patitacaṇḍāla sūtikādyēkāśanaspr̥ṣṭitatspr̥ṣṭyupasparśanē sacēlamiti gautama । [#4]tasminviṣaya idamucyatē āsanatayā śayanatayā vā
suṣṭhvāstīrṇaḥ palālādisaṅghātaḥ svastaraḥ । pr̥ṣōdarādiṣu darśanādrūpasiddhiḥ । yatrātiślakṣṇatayā palālādērmūlāgravibhāgō na jñāyatē sa mr̥ḍhaḥ । mūḍhaścāsau svastaraśca mūḍhasvastara tasmin patitādiṣvaprayatēṣvāsīnēṣu yaḥ kaścitprayata upaviśēt na ca tān saṁspr̥śēt । tadā sa prayatō manyēta । yathā prayatamātmānaṁ manyatē prayatō'smīti tathaiva manyēta । naivaṁvidhē viṣayē tatpr̥ṣṭinyāyaḥ pravartatē iti ॥ 13 ॥

[#3]:

    gau0 dha0 14 30. udakyā rajasvalā  

[#4]:

    tatrēdamucyata iti ga. pu. pāṭhassamīcīnaḥ ।
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

tathā tr̥ṇakāṣṭhēṣu nikhātēṣu 14
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

14. (The same rule applies, if he is seated) on grass or wood fixed in the ground. [#9] 

[#9]:  Haradatta's commentary is of little use, and I am not quite certain that my translation is correct.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
tathā tr̥ṇakāṣṭhēṣu nikhātēṣu ॥ 14 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
tr̥ṇakāṣṭhēṣvapi bhūmau nikhātēṣu tatspr̥ṣṭinyāyō na bhavati ॥14॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

prōkṣya vāsa upayōjayēt 15
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

15. He shall put on a dress, (even if it is clean,) only after having sprinkled it with water. [#10] 

[#10]:  Manu V, 118.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
prōkṣya vāsa upayōjayēt ॥ 15 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
śuddhamapi vāsa prōkṣyaivōpayōjayēt vasīta । apara āha-aśuddhasyāpi vāsasaḥ prōkṣaṇamēva śuddhihēturiti ॥ 15 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

- śūnōpahataḥ sacēlō 'vagāhēta 16
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

16. If he has been touched by a dog, he shall bathe, with his clothes on;
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
śunōpahataḥ sacēlō'vagāhēta ॥ 16 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
śunā upahataḥ spr̥ṣṭaḥ । yadyapi cēlaṁ na śunā spr̥ṣṭa tathāpi sacēlō'vagāhēta bhūmigatāsvapsu snāyāt nōddhr̥tādibhiḥ । daṣṭasya tu smr̥tyantarē prāyaścittam । tatra vasiṣṭhaḥ[#1]  
brāhmaṇastu śunā daṣṭō nadī gatvā samudragām ।   prāṇāyāmaśataṁ kr̥tvā ghr̥taṁ prāśya viśuddhyati।"   
aṅgirāḥ—  
[#2] brahmacārī śunā daṣṭastrirātrēṇaiva śudyati ।   gr̥hasthastu dvirātrēṇa hyēkāhēnā'gnihōtravān ॥   nābhērūrdhvaṁ tu daṣṭasya tadēva dviguṇaṁ bhavēt ।  
tadēva triguṇaṁ vaktrē mūrdhni cētsyāccaturguṇam ॥  
kṣatraviṭchūdrayōnistu snānēnaiva śucirbhavēt ।   dviguṇaṁ tu vanasthasya tathā pravrajitasya ca ॥  
brāhmaṇī tu śunā daṣṭā sōmē dr̥ṣṭiṁ nipātayēt ।  
yadā na dr̥śyatē sōmaḥ prāyaścittaṁ tadā katham ।  
yāṁ diśaṁ tu gatassāmastāṁ diśaṁ tvavalōkayēt ॥  
sōmamārgēṇa sā pūtā pañcagavyēna śuddhati ॥ iti ॥ 16 ॥  

[#1]:

    vacanamidaṁ na vasiṣṭhasmr̥tāvupalabhyatē ।

[#2]:

    vacanānīmāni smr̥timuktāphalakārairapi prāyaścittakāṇḍē aṅgirōvacanatvēnaivōpanyastāni । parantu idānīmupalabhyamānamudritāṅgiraḥ smr̥tipustakē nōpalabhyantē ॥ vāsiṣṭhatvēna tu likhitaṁ kha. ca. pustakayōṣṭippaṇyām ।
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

prakṣālya vā taṁ dēśam agninā saṁspr̥śya punaḥ prakṣālya pādau cācamya prayatō bhavati 17
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

17. Or he becomes pure, after having washed that part (of his body) and having touched it with fire and again washed it, as well as his feet, and having sipped water. [#11] 

[#11]:  This second proceeding is adopted in case the dog has touched the hands or the lower parts of the body, as may be learnt by the comparison of a verse of Manu.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
prakṣālya vā taṁ dēśamagninā saṁspr̥śya punaḥ prakṣālya pādau cā''camya prayatō bhavati ॥ 17 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
śunā spr̥ṣṭaṁ pradēśaṁ prakṣālyāgninā ca saṁspr̥śya punaśca prakṣālya pādau ca prakṣālya paścādācamya prayatō bhavati । vyavasthitavikalpō'yam ॥  
[#1]ūrdhva nābhēḥ karau muktvā yadaṅgamupahanyatē ।  
tatra snānavidhiḥ prōktō hyadhaḥ prakṣālanaṁ smr̥tam ॥'  
iti mānavē darśanāt ॥ 17 ॥  

[#1]:

    ma0 smr̥0 mudritamanusmr̥tipustakēṣu nāyaṁ ślōka upalabhyatē।
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

agniṁ nāprayata āsīdēt 18
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

18. Unpurified, he shall not approach fire, (so near that he can feel the heat). [#12] 

[#12]:  Manu IV, 142; Yājñ. I, 155.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
agniṁ nāprayata āsīdēt ॥ 18 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
aprayatassannagniṁ nāsīdēt agnērāsannō na bhavēt , yāvati dēśē ūṣmōpalambhaḥ । tatrāpyaśaktau na dōṣaḥ ॥ 18 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

iṣumātrādityēkē 19
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

19. Some declare, that (he shall not approach nearer) than the length of an arrow.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
iṣumātrādityēkē ॥ 19 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
iṣumātrādarvāṅnāsīdēt । ūṣmōpalambhō bhavatu vā mā bhūdityēkē manyantē ॥ 19 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

na cainamupadhamēt 20
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

20. Nor shall he blow on fire with his breath. [#13] 

[#13]:  Manu IV, 53. Haradatta mentions other explanations of this Sūtra. Some say, that the Śrauta fire may be kindled by blowing, because that is ordained particularly in the Vājasaneyaka, but that the domestic fire is not to be treated so. Others again consider the rule absolute, and say, that a hollow reed or bellows must be used for kindling the fire, lest drops of saliva should fall upon it.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
na cainamupadhamēt ॥ 20 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
aprayata ityēva । ēnamagnimaprayatō nōpadhamēt । prayatasya na dōṣaḥ।  
'mukhēnōpadhamēdagniṁ mukhāgnirajāyata ।'  
iti smr̥tyantarē darśanāt ।  
[#2] 'nāgniṁ mukhēnōpadhamē'diti mānavē darśanādubhayōrvikalpaḥ। apara āha- vājasanēyē śrautaprakaraṇē 'mukhāddhyagnirajāyata । tasmānmukhēnōpasamindhyā'diti darśanāt śrautēṣu mukhēnōpasamindhanam , anyatra smārtē
pratiṣēdha iti।  
anyē tu vaiṇavēnāyasēna vā suṣirēṇōpasamindhanamicchanti । ēvaṁ hi mukhavyāpārasyānvayācchrutirapyanugr̥hītā bhavati, āsyabindūnāṁ patanaśaṅkābhayāt pratiṣēdhasmr̥tirapīti ॥ 20॥  

[#2]: ma0 smr̥0 4. 53.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

khaṭvāyāṁ ca nōpadadhyāt 21
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

21. Nor shall he place fire under his bedstead. [#14] 

[#14]:  Manu IV, 54.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
khaṭvāyāṁ ca nōpadadhyāt ॥ 21 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
khaṭvāyāṁ khaṭvāyā adhō'gniṁ nōpadhyāt । atrāpyaśaktau na dōṣaḥ ॥21॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

prabhūtaidhōdakē grāmē yatrātmādhīnaṁ prayamaṇaṁ tatra vāsō dhārmyō brāhmaṇasya 22
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

22. It is lawful for a Brāhmaṇa to dwell in a village, where there is plenty of fuel and water, (and) where he may perform the rites of purification by himself. [#15] 

[#15]:  The last condition mentioned in the Sūtra indicates, that the place must have a river or tank, not wells only, as the purification by sipping water cannot be performed without help, with water from wells.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
prabhūtaidhōdakē grāma yatrā''tmādhīnaṁ prayamaṇaṁ tatra vāsō dhārmyō brāhmaṇasya ॥ 21॥  

**ṭīkā**  
prabhūtaṁ ēdhaḥ udakaṁ ca yasmin grāmē tatra vāsō dhārmyaḥ dharmyaḥ । atrāpi na sarvatra । kiṁ tarhi ? yatrātmādhīna prayamaṇaṁ prāyatyaṁ mūtrapurīṣaprakṣālanādīni yatrātmādhīnāni tatra । yatra tu kūpēṣvēvōdakaṁ tatra bahukūpē'pi na vastavyam । brāhmaṇagrahaṇādvarṇāntarasya na dōṣaḥ । grāmagrahaṇādēvaṁbhūtēṣu ghōṣādiśvapi na vastavyam ॥ 22 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

- mūtraṁ kr̥tvā purīṣaṁ vā mūtrapurīṣa-lēpān annalēpān ucchiṣṭalēpān rētasaś ca yē lēpās, tān prakṣālya pādau ca, +ācamya prayatō bhavati 23
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

23. When he has washed away the stains of urine and fæces after voiding urine or fæces, the stains of food (after dinner), the stains of the food eaten the day before (from his vessels), and the stains of semen, and has also washed his feet and afterwards has sipped water, he becomes pure. [#16] 

[#16]:  Manu V, 138.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
mūtraṁ kr̥tvā purīṣaṁ vā mūtrapurīṣalēpānannalēpānucchiṣṭalēpān rētasaśca yē lēpāstānprakṣālya pādau cā''campa prayatō bhavati ॥ 23 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
mūtraṁ purīṣa vā kr̥vā utsr̥jya tayōrmutrapurīṣayōryē lēpāstasminpradēśē sthitāḥ pradēśāntarē vā patitāḥ tān sarvān । [#1]annalēpāṁścānucchiṣṭānapi ucchiṣṭalēpāṁścānannalēpānapi । tathā rētasaśca yē lēpāḥ svapnādau maithunē vā tān sarvānadbhirmr̥dā ca prakṣālya pādau ca lēpavarjitāvapi prakṣālya paścādācamya prayatō bhavati । atra mr̥tpramāṇasya saṅkhyāyāścānuktatvāt yāvatā gandhalēpakṣayō bhavati tāvadēva vivakṣitam । tathā ca yājñavalkyaḥ—  
[#2]gandhalēpakṣayakaraṁ śaucaṁ kuryādatandritaḥ।' iti ।  
dēvalastu vyaktamāha—  
[#3] yāvatsa śuddhiṁ manyēta tāvacchaucaṁ samācarēt ।  
pramāṇaṁ śaucasaṅkhyāyā na śiṣṭairupadiśyatē ॥' iti ।  
paiṭhīnasi -  
'mutrōccārē kr̥tē śaucaṁ na syādantarjalāśayē।  
anyatrōddhr̥tya kuryāttu sarvadaiva samāhitaḥ।' iti ॥ 23 ॥  

[#1]:

    annalē pānucchiṣṭānaṣyucchiṣṭalēpānannalēpānapi. iti kha. pustakē'papāṭhaḥ ।  

[#2]: yā0 smr̥0 1. 17.  

[#3]:

    mudritadēvalasmr̥tāvidaṁ vacanaṁ nōpalabhyatē ।  

ityāpastambadharmasūtravr̥ttau pañcadaśī kaṇḍikā ॥
</details>
</details>

### 16 abhōjyādi

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

tiṣṭhanna+ācāmētprahvō vā 1
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

1. He shall not drink water standing or bent forwards. [#1] 

[#1]:  16. Haradatta takes ācam here to mean 'to drink water,' and thinks that it is forbidden to do this standing or in a bent position. Others refer the prohibition to 'sipping water for the sake of purification,' and translate, 'He shall not sip water standing or in a bent position (except in case of necessity),' i.e. if the bank of the river is so high that he cannot reach the water sitting down, and in this case he shall enter it up to his thighs or up to his navel.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
tiṣṭhannā''cāmēt prahvō vā ॥1॥  
###### ṭappanī
tiṣṭhan prahvō vā nācāmēt । nāyaṁ pratiṣēdhaḥ śakyō vaktum । katham ? 'āsīnastrirācāmē'(162.)diti vakṣyati । tataśca yathā śayānasyācamanaṁ na bhavati tathā tiṣṭhataḥ prahvasya ca na bhavati । ēvaṁ tarhi śaucārthasyācamanasya nāyaṁ pratiṣēdhaḥ । kiṁ tarhi ? pānīyapānasya pratiṣēdhaḥ । tathā gautamaḥ [#1] nāñjalinā jalaṁ pibēt । na tiṣṭha'nniti । apara āha-asmādēva pratiṣēdhātkvacittiṣṭhataḥ prahvasya cā''camanamabhyanujñātaṁ bhavati । tēna 'bhūmigatāsvapsvi'tyatra tīrasyā'yōgyatvē ūrudadhnē [#2]jānudadhnē vā jalē sthitasyā'camanaṁ bhavati । gautamīyē'pi[#3] na tiṣṭhannuddhr̥tōdakēnācāmē'diti sūtracchēdāduddhr̥tōdakēnaiva tiṣṭhataḥ pratiṣēdha iti ॥ 1 ॥  

[#1]: gau0 dha0 9. 9, 10.  

[#2]: nābhidadhnē, iti ca. pu  

[#3]:

    gau0 9. 10 gautamō'pi na tiṣṭhannuddhr̥tōdakēnācāmēt iti sūtrabhēdāduddhr̥tōdakēnaiva tiṣṭhataḥ pratiṣēdhamāha” iti ka. pu.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

āsīnastrirācāmēddhr̥dayaṅgamābhiradbhiḥ 2
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

2. Sitting he shall sip water (for purification) thrice, the water penetrating to his heart. [#2] 

[#2]:  Manu II, 60 and 62; V, 139; and Yājñ. I, 20 and 27; Weber. Ind. Stud. X, 165. Haradatta observes, that the further particulars regarding purification by sipping water must be supplied from other Smṛtis. The rule quoted by him is as follows: 'The performer should be sitting in a pure place, not on a seat, except when sipping water after dinner, and should sip thrice from his hand water which is free from bubbles and foam, and which he has attentively regarded, in such a quantity as would cover a Māṣa-bean. p. 58 The water sipped by a Brahman should reach his heart, that sipped by a Kṣatriya the throat, and that sipped by a Vaiśya the palate. A Śūdra sips once as much as to wet his tongue.'
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
āsīnastrirācāmēddhr̥dayaṅgamābhiradbhiḥ ॥ 2 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
adbhiḥ tr̥tīyā dvitīyārthē । atrā'nuktaṁ smr̥tyantaravaśā[#4]dupaskriyatē। āsīnaḥ śucau dēśē, nāsanē, bhōjanāntē tvāsanē । dakṣiṇaṁ bāhu[#5] jānvantarē kr̥tvā prāṅmukha upaviṣṭaḥ udaṅmukhō vā hr̥dayaṅgamā[#6] apa karatalasthāsu yāvatīṣu māṣō nimajjati tāvatī phēnabudbudarahitāḥ vīkṣitāstrirācāmēt pibēt , brāhmaṇaḥ hr̥dayaṅgamāḥ, kṣatriyaḥ kaṇṭhagatāḥ, vaiśyastālugatāḥ, śūdrō jihvāspr̥ṣṭāssakr̥t ॥ 2॥  

[#4]: 'upastūyatē' iti ga. pu.  

[#5]: ūrvantarē iti. kha ga. pu.  

[#6]: āpaḥ iti. kha. ga. pu.
</details>
</details>

    idamagrimaṁ ca sūtramēkīkr̥taṁ. ga. pustakē,

madhyamābhistisr̥bhiraṅgulībhirōṣṭhau ॥ 5 ॥

6. Some (declare, that he shall do so) twice.

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

dakṣiṇēna pāṇinā savyaṁ prōkṣya, pādau śiraścēndriyāṇyupaspr̥śēc cakṣuṣī nāsikē śrōtrē ca 7
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

7. Having sprinkled water on his left hand with his right, he shall touch both his feet, and his head and (the following three) organs, the eyes, the nose, and the ears. [#3] 

[#3]:  The eyes are to be touched with the thumb and the fourth finger, either at once, or one after the other, the nostrils with the thumb and the second finger, the ears with the thumb and the small finger.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
dakṣiṇēna pāṇinā savyaṁ prōkṣya pādau śiraścēndriyāṇyupaspr̥śēt cakṣuṣī nāsikē śrōtrē ca ॥7॥  

**ṭīkā**  
dakṣiṇēna pāṇinā savyaṁ pāṇiṁ prōkṣya tathā pādau śiraśca, indriyāṇyupaspr̥śēt aṅgulībhiḥ । sarvēṣāmindriyāṇāṁ prasaṅgē parisañcaṣṭē-cakṣuṣī nāsikē śrōtrē cē'ti । indriyāṇīti vacanaṁ svarūpakathanamātram । tatrā'ṅguṣṭhānāmikābhyāṁ cakṣuṣī । kēcidyugapat , kēcitpr̥thak । aṅguṣṭhapradēśinībhyāṁ nāsikē । aṅguṣṭhakaniṣṭhikābhyāṁ śrōtrē । [#1]atra sahabhāvasyā'śakyatvāt pr̥thagbhāvasya niścitatvāt pūrvatrāpi pr̥thagēvēti yuktam ॥ 7 ॥  

[#1]:

    atra sahabhāvasyāśakyatvāt pr̥thagapikriyatē । atra pr̥thakbhāvasya niścitatvāt pūrvatrāpi pr̥thagēvēti yuktam iti kha, ca. pu. । yuktamityanyē iti. ka pu.
</details>
</details>

athāpa upaspr̥śēt 8

athā'pa upaspr̥śēt ॥ 8॥

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

bhōkṣyamāṇastu prayatō'pi dvirācāmēddviḥ parimr̥jētsakr̥dupaspr̥śēt 9
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

9. But if he is going to eat he shall, though pure, twice sip water, twice wipe (his mouth), and once touch (his lips). [#4] 

[#4]:  Manu V, 138.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
bhōkṣyamāṇastu prayatō'pi dvirācāmēddviḥ parimr̥jētsakr̥dupaspr̥śēt ॥9॥  

**ṭīkā**  
bhōjanaṁ kariṣyan prayatō'pi dvirācamanaṁ kuryāt । atra viśēṣaḥ-dviḥ parimr̥jēt , na vikalpēna triḥ। sakr̥dupaspr̥śēt , na vikalpēna dviḥ । 'prayatō'pī'ti vacanādaprāyatyē sarvatra dvirācamanamācāryasyā'bhiprētam ।  
tatra smr̥tyantaram—  
'bhuktvā kṣuttvā ca suptvā ca ṣṭhīvitvōktvā'nr̥taṁ vacaḥ।  
ācāntaḥ punarācāmēdvāsō viparidhāya ca ॥ 9 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

śyāvāntaparyantāv ōṣṭhāv upaspr̥śyācāmēt 10
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

10. He shall rub the gums and the inner part of his lips (with his finger or with a piece of wood) and then sip water.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
śyāvāntaparyantāvōṣṭhāvupaspr̥śyā''cāmēt ॥ 10॥  

**ṭīkā**  
dantamūlātprabhr̥tyōṣṭhau । tatrā'lōmakaḥ pradēśaḥ śyāvaḥ। tasyāntaḥ salōmakaḥ। tatparyantāvōṣṭhāvupaspr̥śyā''cāmēt । ōṣṭhayōralōmakapradēśamaṅgulyā[#2] kāṣṭhādinā vōpaspr̥śyā''cāmēditi ॥ 10 ॥  

[#2]:

    aṅgulyā''tmakaniṣṭhādinā vēti ka. pustakē'papāṭhaḥ ।
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

- na śmaśrubhir ucchiṣṭō bhavaty antarāsyē sadbhir yāvan na hastēnōpaspr̥śati 11
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

11. He does not become impure by the hair (of his moustaches) getting into his mouth, as long as he does not touch them with his hand. [#5] 

[#5]:  Haradatta observes that this Sūtra shows, that every other foreign substance brought with the food into the mouth, makes the food 'leavings' and the eater impure. Manu V, 141.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
na śmaśrubhirucchiṣṭō bhavatyantarāsyē sadbhiryāvanna hastēnōpaspr̥śati ॥ 11 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
śmaśrūṇi yadā āsyasyāntarbhavanti tadā tairantarāsyē sadbhirucchiṣṭō na bhavati yāvanna hastēnōpaspr̥śati । [#1]upasparśanē tūcchiṣṭō bhavati । tataścā''cāmēditi । asmādēva pratiṣēdhāt jñāyatē-yatkiñcidapi dravyamantarāsyē [#2]saducchiṣṭatāyā nimittamiti ॥ 11 ॥  

[#1]: sparśanē iti ka. pu.  

[#2]:

    sat taducchiṣṭatāyā nimittamiti ka. pu.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

- ya āsyādbindavaḥ patanta upalabhyantē tēṣvācamanaṁ vihitam 12
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

12. If (in talking), drops (of saliva) are perceived to fall from his mouth, then he shall sip water. [#6] 

[#6]:  Manu V, 141 declares sipping to be unnecessary in this case.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
ya āsyādbindavaḥ patanta upalabhyantē tēṣvācamanaṁ vihitam ॥ 12 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
bhāṣamāṇasyā''syāt patantō yē lālābindava upalabhyantē cakṣuṣā sparśanādvā upalavdhuṁ yōgyāstēṣvācamanaṁ vihitam । vēdōccāraṇē tu gautamaḥ [#3] mantrabāhmaṇamuccārayatō yē bindavaḥ śarīrē upalabhyantē na tēṣvācamanamiti ॥ 12॥  

[#3]:

    nāsti vacanamidaṁ mudritagautamadharmakōśēṣu madīyē likhitapustakē ca ।
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

yē bhūmau na tēṣvācāmēdityēkē 13
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

13. Some declare, that if (the saliva falls) on the ground, he need not sip water.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
yē bhūmau na tēṣvācāmēdityēkē ॥ 13 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
yē bindavō bhūmau patanti, na śarīrē, tēṣu nācāmēdityēkē manyantē । svamatē tu tēṣvapyācāmēditi ॥ 13 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

- svapnē kṣavathau śr̥ṅkhāṇikā+++(=nāsāmalam)+++-''śrv-ālambhē, lōhitasya kēśānām, agnēr, gavāṁ, brāhmaṇasya, striyāś cālambhē, mahāpathaṁ ca gatvā 'mēdhyaṁ cōpaspr̥śyāprayataṁ ca manuṣyaṁ, nīvīṁ ca paridhāya +apa upaspr̥śēt 14
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

14. On touching during sleep or in sternutation the effluvia of the nose or of the eyes, on touching blood, hair, fire, kine, a Brāhmaṇa, or a woman, and after having walked on the high road, and after having touched an (thing or man), and after having put on his lower garment, he shall either bathe or sip or merely touch water (until he considers himself clean). [#7] 

[#7]:  Manu V, 145.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
svapnē kṣavadhau [#4]śiṅghāṇikāśvālambhē lōhitasya kēśānāmagnērgavāṁ brāhmaṇasya striyāścālambhē mahāpathaṁ ca gatvā'mēdhyaṁ cōpaspr̥śyā'prayataṁ ca manuṣyaṁ nīvīṁ ca paridhāyā'pa upaspr̥śēt ॥ 14 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
svapnaḥ [#5]svāpaḥ। kṣavadhuḥ kṣutam , tayōḥ kr̥tayōḥ। śiṅghāṇikā nāsikāmalam । aśru nētrajalam, tayōrālambhē sparśē । lōhitasya rudhirasya । kēśānāṁ śirōgatānāṁ bhūmigatānāṁ ca । agnyādīnāṁ caturṇāmālambhē । mahāpathaṁ ca gatvā । amēdhyaṁ ca gōvyatiriktānāṁ mūtrapurīṣādi । tāmbūlaniṣēkādi cōpaspr̥śya । aprayataṁ ca manuṣyamupaspr̥śya । nīvī prasiddhā tadyōgādadhōvāsō lakṣyatē । tacca paridhāyāpa upaspr̥śēt । kēṣucit snānaṁ kēṣucidācamanaṁ kēṣucit sparśanamātraṁ yāvatā prayōta manyatē ॥ 14 ॥  

[#4]:

    śr̥ṅghāṇikā śr̥ṅkhaṇikā śr̥ṅgāṇikā ityapi pāṭhāḥ ।  

[#5]: svāpana iti kha. pu.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

ārdraṁ vā śakr̥d ōṣadhīr bhūmiṁ vā 15
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

15. (Or he may touch) moist cowdung, wet herbs, or moist earth.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
ārdraṁ vā śakr̥dōṣadhīrbhūmiṁ vā ॥ 15 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
[#1]upaspr̥śēdityēva । triśvārdraśabdassambadhyatē liṅgavacanādivipariṇāmēna । ārdraṁ vā śakr̥dupaspr̥śēt ōṣadhīrvā ārdrā , bhūmiṁ vā ārdrām । pūrvōktēṣvēva [#2]kalpēṣu vaikalpikamidam ॥ 15 ॥  

[#1]:

    upaspr̥śēditi vipariṇāmēnētyantō bhāga ka. pustakē nāsti।  

[#2]:

    'sarvēṣu' iti kha. ca.pu । svalpēṣu iti ga. pu.।
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

hiṁsārthēnāsinā māṁsaṁ chinnamabhōjyam 16
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

16. He shall not eat meat which has been cut with a sword (or knife) used for killing.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
hiṁsārthēnā'sinā māṁsaṁ chinnamabhōjyam ॥16॥

**prastāvaḥ**  
ēvamācamanaṁ [#3]saha nimattairuktam । athā'bhakṣyādhikāraḥ—  

**ṭīkā**  
asigrahaṇaṁ kṣurādērupalakṣaṇam । yanmāsaṁ pākakālē hisārthēnā'sinā chinna tadabhōjyam ॥ 16 ॥  

[#3]: 'sānimitta'miti kha. pu.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

dadbhirapūpasya nāpacchindyāt 17
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

17. He shall not bite off with his teeth (pieces from) cakes (roots or fruits).
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
dadbhirapūpasya nā'pacchindyāt ॥ 17 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
apagrahaṇaṁ mūlaphalādērapyupalakṣaṇam । dvitīyārthē ṣaṣṭhī। dantairapūpaṁ nāpacchindyāt । kiṁtu hastādibhirapacchidya bhakṣayēt ॥ 17॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

yasya kulē mriyēta na tatrānirdaśē bhōktavyam 18
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

18. He shall not eat in the house of a (relation within six degrees) where a person has died, before the ten days (of impurity) have elapsed. [#8] 

[#8]:  The term "ten days" is used in order to indicate the time of impurity generally. In some cases, as that of a Kṣatriya, this lasts longer. In other cases, where the impurity lasts thirty-six hours only, (the abstention from dining in such houses is shorter.)'--Haradatta. Manu IV, 217.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
yasya kulē mriyēta na tatrā'nirdaśē bhōktavyam ॥18॥  

**ṭīkā**  
yasya kulē kaścinmriyatē asapiṇḍatāyāṁ satyāṁ [#4]tatrā'nirgatē daśāha na bhōktavyam । 'anirdaśē' ityāśaucakālasyōpalakṣaṇam । tēna kṣatriyādiṣvadhikaṁ pakṣiṇyādiṣu nyūnam ॥ 18 ॥  

[#4]:

    'tatrātītē daśāha bhōktavyam' iti । pu.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

tathānutthitāyāṁ sūtikāyām 19
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

19. (Nor shall he eat in a house) where a lying-in woman has not (yet) come out (of the lying-in chamber), [#9] 

[#9]:  A lying-in woman is impure, and must not be touched during the first ten days after her confinement. During this time, she exclusively occupies the Sūtikāgṛha, or lying-in chamber. Manu IV, 217.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
tathā'nutthitāyāṁ sūtakāyām ॥ 19 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
sūtakā sutikā । tasyāmanutthitāyām । utthānaṁ nāma sutikāgārē nivēśitānāmudakumbhādīnāmapanayanam । tacca daśamē'hani bhavati । [#5] daśamyāmutthitāyā'miti gr̥hyē uktatvāt । atrāpyāśaucakālōpalakṣaṇatvādyāvadāśaucamabhōjanam ।  
atrā'ṅgirāḥ—
'brahmakṣatraviśāṁ bhuktvā na dōṣastvagnihōtriṇām ।  
sūtakē śāva āśauca svasthisañcayanātparam ॥ iti ॥ 19 ॥  

[#5]: āpa0 gr̥0 15.8.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

antaḥśavē ca 20
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

20. (Nor in a house) where a corpse lies. [#10] 

[#10]:  Haradatta remarks that in the case of the death of a person who is not a relation, it is customary to place at the distance of 'one hundred bows' a lamp and water-vessel, and to eat (beyond that distance).
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
antaḥśavē ca ॥ 20 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
yāva[#1]dgrāmānna nirhriyatē śavaḥ tāvattatra na bhōktavyam । ācārastu dhanuśśatādarvāk । tatrāpi pradīpamārōpya udakumbhaṁ cōpanidhāya bhuñjatē yadi [#2]samānavaśaṁ gr̥haṁ na bhavati ॥ 20 ॥  

[#1]: grāmāntaṁ na iti ka. pu.  

[#2]:

    samānavaṁśatvaṁ gr̥hāṇā iti kha, pu.। samānaṁ vaṁśagr̥haṁ na bhavati iti ka. pustakē'papāṭhaḥ।
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

aprayatōpahatam annam aprayataṁ, na tv abhōjyam 21

<details><summary>viśvāsa-ṭippanī</summary>

aprayatam annam  
agnāv adhiśritam  
adbhiḥ prōkṣitaṁ  
bhasmanā mr̥dā vā saṁspr̥ṣṭaṁ  
vācā ca praśastaṁ  
prayataṁ bhavati  
bhōjyaṁ ca ।
</details>
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

21. Food touched by a (Brāhmaṇa or other high-caste person) who is impure, becomes impure, but not unfit for eating. [#11] 

[#11]:  'Food which is simply impure, may be purified by putting it on the fire, sprinkling it with water, touching it with ashes or earth, and praising it.'--Haradatta.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
aprayatōpahatamannamaprayataṁ na tvabhōjyam ॥ 21 ॥

**ṭīkā**  
aprayatēnā'śucinā **upahataṁ** spr̥ṣṭam **aprayataṁ** bhavati ।  
kiṁ **tu** aśuddham apy **abhōjyaṁ na** bhavati । 

kaḥ punar aprayatasyā'bhōjyasya ca viśēṣaḥ ? ucyatē-  
aprayatam annam  
agnāv adhiśritam  
adbhiḥ prōkṣitaṁ  
bhasmanā mr̥dā vā saṁspr̥ṣṭaṁ  
vācā ca praśastaṁ prayataṁ bhavati  
bhōjyaṁ ca । 

abhōjyaṁ tu laśunādi na kathañcid apīti ॥ 21॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

aprayatēna tu śūdrēṇōpahr̥tam abhōjyam 22
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

22. But what has been brought (be it touched or not) by an impure Śūdra, must not be eaten, [#12] 

[#12]:  Others say, that the food becomes unfit for eating, only, if in bringing it, the Śūdra has touched it.--Haradatta.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
aprayatēna tu śūdrēṇōpahr̥tamabhōjyam ॥ 22 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
**aprayatēna tu śūdēṇōpahr̥tam** ānītam annaṁ **na bhōjyam** - spr̥ṣṭam aspr̥ṣṭaṁ ca ।  
spr̥ṣṭam ēvētyanyē ॥ 22 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

yasmiṁś cānnē kēśaḥ syāt +++(pākāvasthāyāṁ sati bhinnā vārtā)+++ 23
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

23. Nor that food in which there is a hair, [#13] 

[#13]:  Manu IV, 207; Yājñ. I, 167. 'But this rule holds good only if the hair had been cooked with the food. If a hair falls into it at dinner, then it is to be purified by an addition of clarified butter, and may be eaten.'--Haradatta.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
yasmiścā''nnē kēśasyāt ॥ 23 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
tadapyabhōjyam । ētacca pākadaśāyāmēva patitēna kēśēna saha yatpakvamannaṁ tadviṣayam । [#3]paścāt kēśasaṁsargē tu ghr̥taprakṣēpādinā saṁskr̥tasya bhōjyatvaṁ smr̥tyantarōktam ॥ 23 ॥  

[#3]:

    bhōjanakālē tu kēśapātē ghr̥taprakṣēpādinā tu saṁskr̥taṁ bhōjyam । iti. gha. pu.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

anyad vāmēdhyam 24
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

24. Or any other unclean substance. [#14] 

[#14]:  Haradatta quotes a passage from Baudhāyana, which enumerates as 'unclean things' here intended, 'hair, worms or beetles, nail-parings, excrements of rats.' The rule must be understood as the preceding, i.e. in case these things have been cooked with the food.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
anyadvā'mēdhyam ॥ 24 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
anyadvā'mēdhyaṁ nakhādi yasminnannē syāt tadapyabhōjyam । idamapi pūrvavata । [#4] kēśakīṭanakharōmākhupurīṣāṇi dr̥ṣṭvā tāvanmātramannamuddhr̥tya śēṣaṁ bhōjya'miti । vasiṣṭhastu [#5]'kāmaṁ tu kēśakīṭānutsr̥jyādbhiḥ prōkṣya bhasmanā'vakīrya vācā praśastamupayuñjītē'ti ॥ 24 ॥  

[#4]: bau0 dha0 2. 12. 6  

[#5]:

    vā0 dha0 14. 23 upabhuñjīta iti ga. pu.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

amēdhyair avamr̥ṣṭam 25
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

25. (Nor must that food be eaten) which has been touched with an unclean substance (such as garlic),
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
amēdhyairavamr̥ṣṭam ॥ 25 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
amēdhyaiḥ kalañja-palāṇḍvādibhir avamr̥ṣṭaṁ spr̥ṣṭam abhōjyam ॥ 25 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

kīṭō vāmēdhya-sēvī 26
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

26. Nor (that in which) an insect living on impure substances (is found), [#15] 

[#15]:  Manu IV, 207: Yājñ. I, 167, 168. This Sūtra must be read with Sūtra 23 above.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
kīṭō vā'mēdhyasēvī ॥ 26 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
'yasmiścānnē kēśaḥ syādi'ti vyavahitam avisambadhyatē । amēdhyasēvī kīṭaḥ pūtyaṇḍākhyaḥ ॥ 26 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

mūṣakalāṅgaṁ vā 27
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

27. Nor (that in which) excrements or limbs of a mouse (are found),
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
mūṣikalāṅgaṁ vā ॥ 27 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
pūrvavatsambandhaḥ । **mūṣikalā** mūṣikapūrīṣam । **aṅgaṁ** vā । samastamapi mūṣikagrahaṇaṁ sambadhyatē । yasminnannē mūṣikasyāṅgaṁ pucchapādādi bhavati tadapyabhōjyam ॥ 27॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

padā vōpahatam 28
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

28. Nor that which has been touched by the foot (even of a pure person),
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
padā vōpahatam ॥ 28 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
prayatēnā'pi padā yaspr̥ṣṭaṁ tadapyabhōjyam ॥ 28 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

sicā +++(vastrāñcalēna)+++ vā 29
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

29. Nor what has been (touched) with the hem of a garment,
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
sicā vā ॥ 29 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
sik vastradaśā । parihitasya vāsasaḥ sicā yat spr̥ṣṭaṁ tadapyabhōjyam ॥ 29 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

śunā vāpapātrēṇa vā dr̥ṣṭam 30
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

30. Nor that which has been looked at by a dog or an Apapātra, [#16] 

[#16]:  Manu IV, 208; Yājñ. I, 167. Apapātras are persons whom one must not allow to eat from one's dishes, e.g. Caṇḍālas, Patitas, a woman in her courses or during the ten days of impurity after confinement. See also above, I, 1, 3, 25.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
śunā vā'papātrēṇa vā dr̥ṣṭam ॥ 30॥  

**ṭīkā**  
dr̥ṣṭamiti pratyēkamabhisambadhyatē । śunā vā dr̥ṣṭamapapātrēṇa vā dr̥ṣṭaṁ yattadapyabhōjyam । patitasūtikācaṇḍālōdakyādayō'papātrāḥ, apagatā pātrēbhyaḥ । na hi tē pātrē bhōktuṁ labhantē ॥ 30॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

sicā vōpahr̥tam 31
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

31. Nor what has been brought in the hem of a garment, (even though the garment may be clean),
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
sicā vōpahr̥tam ॥ 31 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
aparihitasya śuddhasyāpi vāsasassicā yad upahr̥tamānītaṁ tadapyabhōjyam ॥ 31 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

dāsyā vā naktamāhr̥tam 32
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

32. Nor what has been brought at night by a female slave. [#17] 

[#17]:  Haradatta thinks, that as the Sūtra has the feminine gender, dāsī, it does not matter if a male slave brings the food. But others forbid also this.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
dāsyā vā naktam āhr̥tam ॥ 32 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
dāsyā rātrāv āhr̥tam abhōjyam । strīliṅganirdēśāt dāsēnā''hr̥tē na dōṣaḥ। anyē liṅgamavivakṣitaṁ manyantē । 'nakta'miti vacanād divā na dōṣaḥ ॥ 32 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

bhuñjānaṁ vā 33
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

33. If during his meal,
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
bhuñjānaṁ vā ॥ 33 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  

॥ ityāpastambadharmasūtravr̥ttau ṣōḍaśī kaṇḍikā ॥
</details>
</details>

### 17 abhōjyādi

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

yatra śūdra upaspr̥śēt 1
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

1. A Śūdra touches him, (then he shall leave off eating). [#1] 

[#1]:  17. 'Some say, that this Sūtra indicates that the touch of a Śūdra does not defile at any other time but at dinner, whilst others hold that a Śūdra's touch defiles always, and that the Sūtra is intended to indicate an excess of impurity, if it happens at dinnertime.'--Haradatta.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
yatra śudra upaspr̥śēt ॥1॥  
**ṭīkā**    
bhōjanadaśāyāṁ yadā śūdra upaspr̥śēt tadāpi na bhuñjīta । atra bhuñjānagrahaṇādanyadā śūdrasparśē nā'prāyatyamiti kēcit । anyē tu- sadā bhavattyēvā'prāyatyam , bhōjanadaśāyāṁ tvādhikyapratipādanāya niṣēdha iti ॥ 1 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

anarhadbhirvā samānapaṅktau 2
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

2. Nor shall he eat sitting in the same row with unworthy people. [#2] 

[#2]:  'Unworthy people are those who are neither of good family, nor possess learning and virtue.'--Haradatta.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
anarhadbhirvā samānapaṅktau ॥ 2 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
sarvatra vāśabdaḥ samuccayē। abhijanavidyāvr̥ttarahitā anarhantaḥ । taissaha samānāyāṁ paṅktau na bhuñjīta ॥2॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

bhuñjānēṣu va yatrānūtthāyōcchiṣṭaṁ prayacchēdācāmēdvā 3
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

3. Nor shall he eat (sitting in the same row with persons) amongst whom one, whilst they eat, rises and gives his leavings to his pupils or sips water; [#3] 

[#3]:  According to Haradatta a person who misbehaves thus, is called 'a dinner-thorn.' This point of etiquette is strictly observed in our days also. Manu IV, 2 12.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
bhuñjānēṣu vā yatrā'nūtthāyōcchiṣṭaṁ prayacchēdācāmēdvā ॥3॥  

**ṭīkā**  
samānapaṅktāviti vartatē । samānapaṅkttau bahuṣu bhuñjānēṣu yadyēkō'nūtthāya bhōjanādviramya ucchiṣṭa śiṣyādibhyaḥ prayacchēt ācāmēdvā, tasyāṁ paṅktāvitarēṣāṁ na bhōktavyam । atō bahuṣu bhuñjānēṣu[#1]ēkō madhyē
na viramēt । bhōjanakaṇṭaka iti hi tamācakṣatē ॥ 3 ॥   

[#1]: kō'pi. iti. ga. pu.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

kutsayitvā vā yatrānnaṁ dadyuḥ 4
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

4. Nor (shall he eat) where they give him food, reviling him. [#4] 

[#4]:  Manu IV, 212; Yājñ. I, 167.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
kutsayitvā vā yatrā'nnaṁ dadyuḥ ॥ 4 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
mūrkha, vaidhavēya, viṣaṁ bhuṅkṣvēti, ēvaṁ kutsayitvā yatrānnaṁ dadyustadapyabhōjyam ॥ 4 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

manuṣyairavaghrātamanyairvāmēdhyaiḥ 5
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

5. Nor (shall he eat) what has been smelt at by men or other (beings, as cats). [#5] 

[#5]:  'As the text has avaghrāta, "smelt at," it does not matter if they smell the food from a distance.'--Haradatta.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
manuṣyairavaghrātamanyairvā'mēdhyaiḥ ॥5॥  

**ṭīkā**  
manuṣyairanyairvā mārjārādibhiramēdhyairavaghrātamannamabhōjyam । [#2]avētyupasargayōgāt durasthairgandhāghrāṇē na dōṣaḥ ॥ 5 ॥  

[#2]:

    avōpasargayōgāt iti ka. pu.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

na nāvi bhuñjīta 6
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

6. He shall not eat in a ship,
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
na nāvi bhuñjīta ॥ 6 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
nāvyāsīnō na bhuñjīta, śuddhē'pi pātrē ॥6॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

tathā prāsādē +++(kāṣṭhamañcē)+++ 7
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

7. Nor on a wooden platform.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
tathā prāsādē ॥ 7॥  

**ṭīkā**  
prāsādō dārumayō mañcaḥ। tatrāpi na bhuñjīta ॥ 7॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

kr̥tabhūmau tu bhuñjīta 8
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

8. He may eat sitting on ground which has been purified (by the application of cowdung and the like).
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
kr̥tabhūmau tu bhuñjīta ॥ 8॥  

**ṭīkā**  
bhūmāvapi bhuñjānaḥ kr̥tāyāṁ gōmayādinā saṁskr̥tāyāṁ bhuñjīta । [#3]apara āha- prāsādō'pi yadā mr̥dā kr̥tabhūmirbhavati, na kēvalaṁ dārumayaḥ, tadā tatra bhuñjītaivēti ॥ 8॥  

[#3]:

    idaṁ vyākhyāntarē nāsti, ga. pustakē ।
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

anāprītē mr̥ṇmayē bhōktavyam 9
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

9. (If he eats) out of an earthen vessel, he shall eat out of one that has not been used (for cooking).
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
anāprītē mr̥ṇmayē bhōktavyam ॥9॥  

**ṭīkā**  
yadi mr̥ṇmayē bhuñjīta tadā'nāprītē bhōktavyam । āprītaṁ kvacitkāryē pākādāvupayuktam ॥ 9 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

āprītaṁ cēd abhidagdhē 10
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

10. (If he can get) a used vessel (only, he shall eat from it), after having heated it thoroughly.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
āprītaṁ cēdabhidagdhē ॥ 10 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
āprītamēva cēllabhyatē, tadā'gninā'bhitō dagdhvā tatra bhōktavyam ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

parimr̥ṣṭaṁ lauhaṁ prayatam 11
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

11. A vessel made of metal becomes pure by being scoured with ashes and the like. [#6] 

[#6]:  'It must be understood from other Smṛtis, that brass is to be cleaned with ashes, copper with acids, silver with cowdung, and gold with water.'--Haradatta. Manu V, I 14.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
parimr̥ṣṭaṁ lauhaṁ prayatam ॥ 11 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
lauha lōhavikārabhūtaṁ kāṁsyādi bhōjanapātraṁ bhasmādibhiḥ parimr̥ṣṭaṁ sat prayata bhavati । tatra bhasmanā kāṁsyam । āmlēna tāmram । rājataṁ śakr̥tā । sauvarṇamadbhirēvētyādi smr̥tyantaravaśāddraṣṭavyam ॥11॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

nirlikhitaṁ dārumayam 12
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

12. A wooden vessel becomes pure by being scraped. [#7] 

[#7]:  Manu V, 115.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
nirlikhitaṁ dārumayam ॥ 12॥  

**ṭīkā**  
dārumayaṁ bhājanaṁ nirlikhitaṁ taṣṭa sat prayataṁ bhavati ॥ 12 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

yathāgamaṁ yajñē 13
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

13. At a sacrifice (the vessels must be cleaned) according to the precepts of the Veda.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
yathāgamaṁ yajñē ॥ 13 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
yajñapātraṁ tu yathāgama śōdhitaṁ prayata bhavati । tadyathā agnihōtrahavaṇī dabhairadbhiḥ prakṣālitā, sōmapātrāṇi [#1]'mārjālīyē prakṣālitāni, ājyapātrāṇyuṣṇēna vāriṇā ॥ 13 ॥  

[#1]:

    mārjālīyaḥ sōmayāgē sadōnāmakamaṇḍapasyāgnēyakōṇē sthitaḥ sthānaviśēṣaḥ ।
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

nā''paṇīyam +++(pakvaṁ)+++ annam aśnīyāt 14
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

14. He shall not eat food which has been bought or obtained ready-prepared in the market.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
nā''paṇīyamannamaśnīyāt ॥ 14 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
āpaṇaḥ paṇyavīthī । tatra yatkrītaṁ labdhaṁ vā । tad **āpaṇīyam** । tacca kr̥tānnaṁ nāśnīyāt । vrīhyādiṣu na dōṣaḥ ॥ 14 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

tathā +++(''paṇiyān)+++ rasān +++(nāśnīyāt)+++, āma+++(=apakva)+++-māṁsa-madhu-lavaṇānīti parihāpya 15
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

15. Nor (shall he eat) flavoured food (bought in the market) excepting raw meat, honey, and salt.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
tathā rasānāmāmamāṁsamadhulavaṇānīti parihāpya ॥15॥  

**ṭīkā**  
**rasāḥ** rasadravyāṇi । tān apy āpaṇīyān nāśnīyāt ।  
[#2]āma-māṁsādi varjayitvā ॥ 15॥  

[#2]: āmamāṁsādīni parihāpya, iti ga. pu.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

taila-sarpiṣī tūpayōjayēd udakē'vadhāya 16
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

16. Oil and clarified butter (bought in the market) he may use, after having sprinkled them with water. [#8] 

[#8]:  'Having sprinkled them with water and purified them by boiling; or, according to others, mixing them with so much water as will not spoil them.'--Haradatta.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
tailasarpiṣī tūpayōjayēdudakē'vadhāya ॥ 16 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
**taila-sarpiṣī** vāpaṇīyē apy upayōjayēt ।  
**udakē'vadhāya** niṣicya pākēna taila-sarpiṣī[#3] śōdhayitvā ।  
kāryavirōdhō yathā na bhavati tathā udakēna saṁsr̥jyētyanyē[#4]॥ 16 ॥  

[#3]:

    śōṣayitvā iti ga. pu.  

[#4]:

    vyācakṣatē ityadhikaṁ kha, ga, pu
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

kr̥tānnaṁ paryuṣitam akhādyāpēyānādyam 17
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

17. Prepared food which has stood for a night, must neither be eaten nor drunk. [#9] 

[#9]:  The Sanskrit has two terms for 'eating;' the first 'khād' p. 63 applies to hard substances, the second 'ad' to soft substances. Manu I, V, 211; Yājñ. I, 16 7.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
kr̥tānnaṁ paryuṣitamakhādyāpēyānādyam ॥ 17 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
**kr̥tānnaṁ** pakvānnaṁ, tat **paryuṣitaṁ** pūrvēdyu pakvaṁ sat **akhādyam** ।  
**apēyam anādyaṁ** ca  
yathāyōgaṁ kharaviśadaṁ dravaṁ mr̥duviśadaṁ siddhaṁ ca ॥ 17 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

śuktaṁ+++(=kāla-pakēnā'mlībhūtaṁ)+++ ca 18
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

18. Nor (should prepared food) that has turned sour (be used in any way). [#10] 

[#10]:  Manu IV, 211; V, 9; Yājñ. I, 167.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
śuktaṁ ca ॥ 18 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
**śuktaṁ** yat kāla-pakēnā'mlībhūtaṁ  
tad aparyuṣitam api  
akhādyāpēyāḥ nādyam ॥ 18॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

phāṇita+++(=śarkararasa)+++-pr̥thuka+++(=ciuḍā)+++-taṇḍula-karamba+++(=dadhi+śaktu)+++-bharuja+++(=bhraṣṭayava)+++-saktu-śāka-māṁsa-piṣṭa-kṣīra-vikārauṣadhi-vanaspati-mūla-phala-varjam 19
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

19. (The preceding two rules do) not (hold good in regard to) the juice of sugar-cane, roasted rice-grains, porridge prepared with whey, roasted yava, gruel, vegetables, meat, flour, milk and preparations from it, roots and fruits of herbs and trees. [#11] 

[#11]:  Manu V, 10, 24 and 25.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
phāṇita-pr̥thuka +++(ciuḍā)+++-taṇḍula-karamba +++(dadhi+śaktu)+++-[#1]bharuja-saktu-śāka-māṁsa-piṣṭa-kṣīravikārauṣadhi-vanaspati-mūla-phala-varjam 19  

**ṭīkā**  
anantarōkta-vidhidvayaṁ phāṇitādīn varjayitvā draṣṭavyam ।  

**phāṇitaṁ** pānaviśēṣaḥ । ikṣurasa iti kēcit ।  
[#2]bhraṣṭānāṁ vrīhīṇāṁ taṇḍulāḥ pr̥thūkr̥tāḥ **pr̥thukāḥ** ।  
**karambō** dadhi-saktu-samāhāraḥ yaḥ karambha iti prasiddhaḥ।  
vēdē'pyubhayaṁ bhavati[#3] 'yatkarambairjuhōti' । [#4] dhānāḥ karambhaḥ parivāpa' iti।  
**bharūjāḥ** bhraṣṭā yavāḥ।  
**kṣīra-vikārō** dadhyādi । prasiddhamanyat ॥  

[#1]:

    'bharujē'ti kha. pu. bharijēti ka. pu.  

[#2]:

    bharjitānāṁ iti. kha pu.  

[#3]:

    tai0 brā0 3. 8. 14.  

[#4]: tai0 saṁ0 6. 5. 11.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

śuktaṁ cāparayōgam 20
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

20. (Substances which have turned) sour without being mixed with anything else (are to be avoided). [#12] 

[#12]:  According to Haradatta, Āpastamba returns once more to the question about sour food, in order to teach that dishes prepared with curds and other sour substances may be eaten.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
śuktaṁ cā'parayōgam ॥ 20॥  

**prastāvaḥ**  
atha 'śuktaṁ cē'tyasya vidhēḥ śēṣaḥ—

**ṭīkā**  
parēṇa dravyāntarēṇa yōgō yasya tat parayōgaṁ, tatō'nyadaparayōgam । tadēva śuktaṁ varjyam । yattu dadhyādi dravyāntarasaṁsr̥ṣṭaṁ śuktaṁ tadbhōjyamēva । ēvaṁ ca pūrvatraivā'parayōgamiti viśēṣaṇaṁ vaktavyam । idamēva vā sūtramastu । sūtradvayakaraṇaṁ tvācāryapravr̥ttikr̥tam। yathā 'salāvr̥kyēkasr̥kōlūkaśabdā' (pr̥. 58) iti pūrvaṁ sāmānyēnā'bhidhāya 'salāvr̥kyāmēkasr̥ka iti svapnaparyānta'(pr̥. 65)miti paścādviśēṣa uktaḥ ॥ 20 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

sarvaṁ madyamapēyam 21
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

21. All intoxicating drinks are forbidden.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
sarvaṁ madyamapēyam ॥ 21 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
madyaṁ madakaraṁ tatsarvamapēyam । atra smr̥tyantaravaśādvyavasthā ।  
tatra manuḥ —  
[#5] 'gauḍī paiṣṭī ca mādhvī ca vijñēyā trividhā surā।  
yathaivaikā na pātavyā[#6] tathā sarvā dvijōttamaiḥ । iti ।   surāvyatiriktaṁ tu madyaṁ brāhmaṇasya nityamapēyam ॥  
tathā ca gautamaḥ—  
[#1] 'madyaṁ nityaṁ brāhmaṇasya kṣatriyavaiśyayōstu brahmacāriṇō'riti ॥21॥  

[#5]: ma0 smr̥0 11. 94  

[#6]: 'tathaivānyā' iti ga pu.  

[#1]:

    gau0 dha0 2. 20 madyaṁ nityaṁ brāhmaṇaḥ, ityēva sūtram ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

tathailakaṁ payaḥ 22
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

22. Likewise sheep's milk, [#13] 

[#13]:  Manu V, 8; Yājñ. I, 170.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
tathailakaṁ payaḥ ॥ 22 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
avi ēlakā। tasyāḥ payaḥ kṣīramapēyam ॥ 22 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

uṣṭrīkṣīra-mr̥gīkṣīra-sandhinīkṣīra-yamasūkṣīrāṇīti 23
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

23. Likewise the milk of camels, of does, of animals that give milk while big with young, of those that bear twins, and of (one-hoofed animals), [#14] 

[#14]:  Manu V, 8, 9; Yājñ. I 170. 'Sandhinī, translated by "females that give milk while big with young," means, according to others, "female animals that give milk once a day."--Haradatta.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
uṣṭrīkṣīramr̥gīkṣīrasandhinīkṣīrayamasūkṣīrāṇīti ॥23॥  

**ṭīkā**  
uṣṭrīmr̥gyau prasiddhē। yā garbhiṇī dugdhē sā sandhinīti śāstrāntarē prasiddhā। ēkakāladōhētyanyē । ēkasmin prasavē yā anēkaṁ garbhaṁ sūtē, sā yamasūḥ। uṣṭryādīnāṁ kṣīrāṇyapēyāni । itikaraṇamēvaṁ prakārāṇāmanyēṣāmēkaśaphādīnāṁ kṣīramapēyamiti ।  
tathā ca manuḥ—  
[#2] āraṇyānāṁ ca sarvēṣāṁ mr̥gāṇāṁ mahiṣīṁ vinā ।   strīkṣīraṁ caiva vāni sarvaśūktāni caiva hi ॥  
anirdaśāyā gōḥ kṣīramauṣṭramaikaśaphaṁ tathā।  
āvikaṁ sandhinīkṣīraṁ vivatsāyāśca gōḥ payaḥ ॥ iti ॥23॥  

[#2]:

    ma0 smr̥0 5. 9, 8.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

dhēnōścānirdaśāyāḥ +++(prasavād 10 dinēbhyaḥ prāk)+++ 24
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

24. Likewise the milk of a cow (buffalo-cow or she-goat) during the (first) ten days (after their giving birth to young ones), [#15] 

[#15]:  Manu V, 8.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
dhēnōścā'nirdaśāyāḥ ॥ 24 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
dhēnurnavaprasūtā gauḥ । cakārādajāmahiṣyōśca । [#3] 'ajā gāvō mahiṣyaścē'ti mānavē darśanāt ॥ 24॥  

[#3]:

    ma0 smr̥0 nāyaṁ ślōkō mānavē upalabhyatē । pratyuta 'anirdaśāyā gōḥ kṣīrē (5. 8) iti ślōkavyākhyānāvasarē kullūkabhēṣṭēna “gōriti pēyakṣīrōpalakṣaṇārtham । tēnājāmahiṣyōrapi daśāhamadhyē pratiṣēdhaḥ, iti lēkhanāt 'ajā gāvō mahiṣyaścē'tyasyā'mānavatvamēvā'numīyatē । vastutastu pārāśarīyaṁ vacanamidam । (parā0 smr̥0 3. 7.) tatraiva darśanāt ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

tathā kīlālauṣadhīnāṁ ca 25
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

25. Likewise (food mixed) with herbs which serve for preparing intoxicating liquors,
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
tathā kīlālauṣadhīnāṁ ca ॥ 25 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
kīlālōṣadhayaḥ surārthā ōṣadhayaḥ । tāsāṁ ca vikārabhūtamannamanādyam ॥ 25 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

karañja-palaṇḍu-parārīkāḥ 26
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

26. (Likewise) red garlic, onions, and leeks, [#16] 

[#16]:  Manu V, 5; Yājñ. I, 176.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
[#4]karañjapalaṇḍuparārīkāḥ ॥26 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
[#5]karajaṁ raktalaśunam । palaṇḍu śvētam । parārīkā kr̥ṣṇam । [#6]maṇḍumākhyayā mlēcchānāṁ prasiddham । ētē cā'bhakṣyāḥ ॥ 26 ॥  

[#4]:

    kalañjapalāṇḍuparārīkāḥ iti ka. pu. parārikāḥ iti gha. pu.  

[#5]:

    anēnaiva pramāṇēna 'na kalañjaṁ bhakṣayēt' ityādau kalañjaśabdō raktalaśunapara ityasmābhirvyākhyātaṁ nañarthanirūpaṇāvasarē mīmāṁsānyāyaprakāśavyākhyāyāṁ sāravivēcinyām । tatra pramāṇāntaramapyupanyastaṁ tatraiva dr̥ṣṭavyam ॥  

[#6]:

    ḍuṇḍubhāvyayā iti kha.pu. suhaṇḍubhākhyayā iti, ka. pu.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

yaccānyat paricakṣatē 27
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

27. Likewise anything else which (those who are learned in the law) forbid. [#17] 

[#17]:  Haradatta observes that Āpastamba, finding the list of forbidden vegetables too long, refers his pupils to the advice of the Śiṣṭas. The force of this Sūtra is exactly the same as that of I, 3, 11, 38.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
yaccā'nyat paricakṣatē ॥ 27 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
abhakṣyānāṁ pratipadapāṭhō na śakyatē iti samāsēnāha—  

**ṭīkā**  
yaccānyadēvaṁyuktaṁ śiṣṭāḥ paricakṣatē varjayanti tadapyabhakṣyam । tatrāha manuḥ—  
[#1]laśunaṁ gr̥ñjanaṁ caiva palaṇḍu kavakāni ca ॥  
abhakṣyāṇi dvijātīnāmamēdhyaprabhavāni ca ॥ iti ॥ 27॥  

[#1]: ma0 smr̥0 5. 5.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

kyākvabhōjyamiti hi brāhmaṇam 28
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

28. Mushrooms ought not to be eaten; that has been declared in a Brāhmaṇa; [#18] 

[#18]:  Yājñ. I, 171.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
kyākvabhōjyamiti hi brāhmaṇam ॥28॥  

**ṭīkā**  
kyāku chatrākaṁ tadabhōjyamabhakṣyam । brāhmaṇagrahaṇamuktārtham ॥ 28 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

ēkakhurōṣṭragavayagrāmasūkaraśarabhagavām 29
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

29. (Nor the meat) of one-hoofed animals, of camels, of the Gayal, of village pigs, of Śarabhas, and of cattle. [#19] 

[#19]:  The camel, Gayal, and Śarabha are mentioned as 'forbidden animals,' Śatapatha-br. I, 2, 1, 8; Aitareya-br. II, 1, 8; see also Weber, Ind. Stud. X, 62; Manu V, 11, 18; Yājñ. I, 172, 176.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
ēkakhurōṣṭragavayagrāmamūkaraśarabhagavām ॥ 29 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
ēkakhurā aśvādayaḥ । gavayō gōsadr̥śaḥ paśuḥ। śarabhō'ṣṭapāda āraṇyō mr̥gaḥ। anyē prasiddhāḥ । ētēṣāṁ māṁsamabhakṣyam ॥ 29 ॥
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

dhēnu+anaḍuhōrbhakṣyam 30
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

kruñca-krauñca-vārdhrāṇasa-lakṣmaṇa-varjam +++(abhakṣyam)+++ 36
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

36. Common cranes and Sāras-cranes (are not to [#24]  be eaten) with the exception of the leather-nosed Lakṣmaṇa.

[#24]:  Manu V, 12; Yājñ. I, 172. Other commentators take the whole Sūtra as one compound, and explain it as an exception to Sūtra 34. In that case the translation runs thus: ('Carnivorous birds are forbidden) except the Kruñca, Krauñca, Vārdhrāṇasa, p. 65 and Lakṣmaṇa.'--Haradatta. This translation is objectionable, because both the Kruñca, now called Kulam or Kūñc, and the Krauñca, the red-crested crane, now called Sāras (Cyrus), feed on grain. Kruñcakrauñca is a Vedic dual and stands for kruñcakrauñcā or kruñcakrauñcau.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
kruñca-krauñca +++(ētēṣu)+++ vārdhrāṇasa-lakṣmaṇa-varjam +++(abhakṣyam)+++ ॥ 36॥  

**ṭīkā**  
kruñcā vr̥ndacārāḥ । krauñcā mithunacarāḥ । tē cā'bhakṣyāḥ । sūtrē krauñcēti vibhaktilōpaśchāndasaḥ । kimaviśēṣēṇa kruñcakrauñcā abhakṣyāḥ। nētyāha-vārdhrāṇasalakṣmaṇavarjam । śvētō lōhitō vā mūrdhā yēṣāṁ tē lakṣmaṇāḥ ta ēva viśēṣyantē-vārdhrāṇasā iti । vārdhraṁ carma tadākārā nāsikā yēṣāṁ tē vārdhrāṇasāḥ। ēvaṁbhūtān lakṣmaṇān varjayitvā kruñcakrauñcā na bhakṣyā iti।  
anyē tvāhuḥ-'kravyāda' iti prāptasya pratiṣēdhasya kruñcādiṣu caturṣvapratiṣēdha iti । tatra lakṣmaṇā sārasī lakṣmaṇavarjamiti[#1] 'ṅyāpōssaṁjñācchandasō'riti hrasvaḥ। ēvaṁ kruñcādiśabdasyā'pyajādiṭābantasya ॥36॥   

[#1]: pā0 sū0 6. 3.63.
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

pañcanakhānāṁ gōdhā-kacchapa-śvāviṭ-śalyaka-khaṇga-śaśa-pūtikhaṣa-varjam 37
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

37. Five-toed animals (ought not to be eaten) with the exception of the iguana, the tortoise, the porcupine, the hedgehog, the rhinoceros, the hare, and the Pūtikhasha. [#25] 

[#25]:  Manu V, 18; Yājñ. I, 77. Pūtikhasha is, according to Haradatta, an animal resembling a hare, and found in the Himālayas.
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
pañcanakhānāṁ[#2] gōdhākacchapaśvāviṭcharyakakhaṅgaśaśapūtikhaṣavarjam ॥ 37 ॥  

**ṭīkā**  
pañcanakhā naravānaramārjārādayaḥ। tēṣāṁmadhyē gōdhādīn sapta varjayitvā anyē abhakṣyāḥ । gōdhā kr̥kalāsākr̥tirmahākāyā । kacchapaḥ kūrmaḥ । śvābiṭ varāhaviśēṣaḥ, yasya nārācākārāṇi lōmāni। śaryakraḥ śalyakaḥ, yasya carmaṇā tanutrāṇaṁ kriyatē । śvāviṭśaryaka iti yuktaḥ pāṭhaḥ। ēkē tu chakāraṁ paṭhanti । chakārātpūrvamikāram । khaṅgō mr̥gaviśēṣaḥ, yasya śr̥ṅgaṁ tailabhājanam । śaśaḥ prasiddhaḥ। pūtikhaṣaḥ । śaśākr̥tiḥ himavati prasiddhaḥ ॥37॥  

[#2]:

    pañcapañcanakhā bhakṣyāḥ, ityatra dvitīyasaptamavarjitānāṁ grahaṇam ।
</details>
</details>

<details open><summary>mūla-prastutiḥ</summary>

abhakṣyaścēṭō matsyānām 38
</details>

<details><summary><h5>sarvāṣ ṭīkāḥ</h5></summary>
<details><summary>Bühler</summary>

38. Amongst fishes, the Ceta ought not to be eaten,
</details>

<details><summary>haradatta-ṭīkā</summary>

**sūtram**  
abhakṣyaścēṭō matsyānām ॥ 38॥  

**ṭīkā**  
matsyānāṁ madhyē cēṭākhyō matsyō na bhakṣyaḥ ॥ 38 ॥
